sect1.title: Creating a Character
sect1.para: The first task that a player has is to create a character. The first stage in the process is to come up with a concept for the character - who they are, what they do, and where they come from. The GM may want to give some guidelines on this, such as character's coming from a particular place, or having a certain profession.
Once the player has a concept firmly in mind, it is time to start solidifying that concept into the framework of the game. To do this, there are three basic steps:

Except for the sunsign, the order in which these are performed is not important, though the above order will be followed in the steps below. The sunsign should be rolled first, and this is the only part of character generation which is random.

sect2.title: Choosing a Race
sect2.para: It is possible to play a non-human character - Sindarin (elves) or Khuzdul (dwarves) are the most common.

If this is desired, then the advantage and disadvantage packages for these races should be perused before making any other decisions. They are given at the end of the advantages section, since they will not make much sense unless the preceding information has been read.

sect2.title: Attributes
sect2.para: The eight attributes listed in the Introduction make up the core definition of a character within the rules. All skills, and therefore any action the character attempts, are based on one of the attributes.

sect3.title: Determine Attribute Scores
sect3.para: The player has 48 points to spend on attributes. The cost of buying attributes is on a pyramid progression - see the chart on this page. A score of one costs one point, whereas a score of three costs six points. An average character, with three in each of the eight attributes (strength, stamina, agility, dexterity, perception, intelligence, charisma, will), costs 48 points.

It is possible to spend more (or less) points on attributes. If necessary, up to a further twenty points can be purchased as advantages. It is also possible to not spend points, in which case this is counted toward the character's disadvantages.
Details about the attributes, and the costs to advance each one, are given in the Introduction. Advantages and disadvantages are explained in the next section.

sect2.title: Sunsign
sect2.para: In Harn, the date of a character's birth can have a real affect on their life. This should be rolled randomly, before the rest of character generation proceeds.

Tuzyn Reckoning (TR) has a 12 month lunar year, and each month has 30 days. Roll d12 to generate the month the character was born, then a d6 followed by a d10 (d6, 1-2 = +0 to d10 roll, 3-4 = +10, 4-6 = +20) to generate the day of the month.

A bonus of +1 applies to the attribute in the given situation. For example, someone born under the sign of Tai with a charisma of 3, would have an effective charisma of 4 when teaching someone, or writing a book.

sect1.title: Advantages and Disadvantages
sect1.para: Advantages are things that give a character an edge over others in the world. Each type of advantage has a point cost, and a character can take up to twenty points worth of advantages, though they can take less if desired.
The majority of people within the world will have significantly less than twenty points, maybe only three or four for typical farmers in the field.

Disadvantages work against a character, and have a negative cost. The total value of advantages and disadvantages taken must total zero or less. You can buy more disadvantages than you have advantages, but no benefit is gained from doing so (other than possibly making for a more interesting character).
The different types of advantages and disadvantages are as follows.

sect2.title: Attributes
sect2.para: Spending more than the normal 48 points on attributes counts as an advantage equal in value to the extra points.
Spending less than the normal 48 points is considered a disadvantage equal to the shortfall.
Many characters will have about five points of advantages spent on attributes. More than ten is unusual.

sect2.title: Appearance
sect2.para: A character's appearance ranges from -6 to +6, and costs 1 point per level. Its level adds to rolls for social skills when dealing with members of the opposite sex.

sect2.title: Edges and Flaws
sect2.para: These modify one or more skills in a given situation. No more than one edge or flaw can apply in a given situation (though a single edge, and a single flaw, can combine). If more than one are applicable, then take whichever has the biggest effect.
All edges and flaws are bought on a level from one to six.

sect3.title: Edges
sect3.para: Edges modify a skill under certain circumstances. For example, the absolute direction edge will give a bonus to survival or area lore rolls, but only when the character is trying to find their way.
Edges range in level from one to six, and give a bonus to skill rolls equal to their level. The cost of an edge is different from its level. Costs are listed as +x/y levels, e.g. +1/2 levels.
Only one edge can ever apply to any given roll.

sect3.title: Flaws
sect3.para: Flaws, similar to edges, give modifiers to skills under certain situations. Unlike edges however, they are detrimental. Further, if the die roll is equal to or less than the value of the flaw, the attempt is an automatic failure (or at least, only a partial success).
If more than one flaw applies to a given roll, then only the worst one will have affect.

sect2.title: Generic Advantages
sect2.para: These cover options which can be either advantages or disadvantages, or which affect the starting state of the character.

sect4.title: Social Class
sect4.para: A character is assumed to be a freeman unless this advantage is taken. The main effect of social rank within the game is to determine the weregild of the character.

sect4.title: Wealth
sect4.para: The wealth of a character is normally related to their social class, though this is not always the case. A very successful merchant could be very rich, but they will still be a mere guilded freeman, of lower rank than a poor nobleman.

A typical freeman will own 100 + d20 x 5 pence in goods and property. Most of this will be property - a house, with a small plot of land, some chickens and maybe a cow. 10% of this may be cash, or other easily exchangeable goods. Cashing in property will be difficult, since there won't be anyone able to afford it, except for the local lord who will probably figure he can just move in anyway for free once the character has vanished off 'adventuring'.

The character templates should give an idea as to how much wealth a character begins with. A mercenary will have a sword and armour in place of land, a merchant may have a small shop, or a caravan and some mules.

If a character is to start with more than the norm, then it costs one point of advantage to increase the amount of wealth by a multiple. One point will double starting wealth, 2 points will triple it etc.

sect4.title: Exceptional Training
sect4.para: The character had an exceptionally active life, and learned far more than their peers. For every point of advantage, they may start the game with two extra points of skills (explained later). Such points may be spent during the character's adulthood, and do not add to the character's age.

sect4.title: Reputation
sect4.para: The reputation of a character can greatly affect how other people react to them. Reputations can be good or bad, and are respectively considered to be an advantage or a disadvantage.

The level of the reputation gives a bonus to people's intelligence - area lore ability as if it were a passion, to see if they recognise you. Other modifiers may be used, as decided by the GM. A reputation must have been gained for some reason, so the player and GM should decide how the character got his reputation.

row.entry: Very minor, the odd person. An area lore roll of 30 will generally be needed.
Minor, a few people. An area lore of 25 will recognise the character.
Moderate, many people. An area lore roll of 20.
Well known, most people will know of the reputation An area lore roll of 15.
Fame or infamy. Practically everyone will be aware of it. An area lore roll of 10 is needed to recognise the character.

sect4.para: The above costs assumes the reputation covers a kingdom, such as Kanday or Rethem. If it is to cover a smaller or larger area, then the cost is modified as follows.

row.entry: A subdivision of a kingdom, such as a shire.
A whole kingdom, such as Kanday, Tharda or Kandor.

sect3.title: Duty
sect3.para: A duty is an obligation to a cause, organisation or person. It can take up much of your time, and you may welcome it, or resent it, but either way, when it calls, you must do your utmost to fulfill it.

A duty is always a disadvantage. The base cost depends on how regularly you will be called on to fulfill your obligations. Each season, the GM will roll 2d10 against the chance given in the duty table. If you are called up to serve a duty, then the amount of time it takes is variable, probably of a few weeks, but could be anything from a day, to a season.

The cost of the duty is multiplied by how much danger is generally involved in carrying out the duty. If you have a duty to serve as judge in a court of law occasionally, then the risk is minimal. If you have a duty to protect a town, which is often raided by giants and dragons, then it could be considered to be perilous. A fyrd duty to a lord would be a common duty, with moderate risk, for a cost of -6.

sect3.title: Allies and Enemies
sect3.para: You can begin the game with a powerful NPC as either a friend or enemy. An ally is considered to be an advantage, whereas an enemy is a disadvantage.

The base cost depends on how frequently the enemy turns up. Each adventure, the GM rolls two dice, and if the target number is met, then the given enemy will be around to make your life more interesting. Likewise, if you try to call on an ally for help, then the chance of them helping is found in a similar way.

It should be noted that a powerful enemy is probably going to send capable henchmen to deal with you pretty rapidly. If they catch you, they'll probably kill you without too much difficulty, so taking such an enemy will mean that you will be on the run for a long time, until you are able to deal with the threat. A very powerful enemy or ally who turns up most of the time will not normally be possible, since the cost exceeds the 20 point limit for characters.

row.entry: Most of the time. 10+ on d20
Power of the Enemy or Ally
Weak. A small group of people with very few resources. Some friends, or a small street gang.
Moderate. A small group of people with the law, and or resources on their side. A local lord for example.

Strong. A strong lord or wizard, or maybe a large group of bandits. They will have friends and contacts to call on, and friends and family to back them up if anything is tried against them directly. The Lia Kavier.
Powerful. A very strong noble, or a large church. Resources and the law are on their side.
An entire kingdom, a very powerful group of wizards or some powerful supernatural entity.

sect2.title: Luck
sect2.para: A character's luck is a measure of how lucky they are. Most people have a luck of zero, which represents being neither particularly lucky nor unlucky. Lucky characters possibly have the favour of a god, or other power, who is looking out for them.
Luck can be gained by taking part in major religious ceremonies. When checking for luck in a situation, roll 1d20, add the character's current luck, and compare against the following difficulties.

row.entry: Very likely. Event is almost certain to occur.
Likely. About 50% chance of event occurring to character's benefit.
Unlikely. Event probably won't occur, but there is a chance which isn't too improbable.
Highly unlikely. If things go to the character's advantage this time, then he is very lucky.
Improbable. The character would have to be extremely lucky for this to happen. The sort of event which is talked about for ages.
Highly improbable. So improbable, that if it does occur, it smacks of divine intervention of some kind.

sect2.para: Luck (+1 / level): This can be taken up to five times, to give the character a +5 luck. Each point of luck gives a +1 bonus on luck rolls. At any time, a luck point can be spent to give a one time immediate effect to get the character out of a sticky situation. The effect is up to the GM, but examples would be that a fatal blow leaves the character wounded and unconscious, a fumble is turned into a simple failure, or a failure into success. Luck is bestowed by the gods, so only characters who are part of a religion can have luck points.

sect2.title: Passions
sect2.para: Passions range in strength from +1 (a slight quirk) to +5 (controls your life). Passions of level +1 or +2 cost nothing, and may be taken freely to round out the character. Passions of +3 or higher must be paid for as advantages or disadvantages.

Most passions are considered disadvantages, since they restrict how a character behaves. There are three broad groups of passions - minor, lesser and greater, which are based on how much effect the passion will have on the character's actions. Greater passions are worth a lot more than minor passions.

sect3.title: Minor Passions (Disadvantages)
sect3.para: Minor passions are worth one, two or four points, depending on whether they are +3, +4 or +5 levels.

sect3.title: Lesser Passions (Advantages)
sect3.para: Lesser passions are worth two, four or eight points, depending on whether they are +3, +4 or +5.

sect3.title: Greater Passions (Disadvantages)
sect3.para: Greater passions are worth three, six or twelve points, depending on whether they are +3, +4 or +5.

sect2.title: Sindarin Advantages
sect2.para: The following advantages are available only to Sindarin characters. Mostly, these allow Sindarin to be good at the things they are famed for cheaply.

sect3.title: Standard Sindarin Advantages
sect3.para: These advantages are common to all Sindarin, and are gained free as part of the Sindarin package.

advantage.name: Immortal
advantage.description: Sindarin are immortal. They can be killed, but will not die of old age. A Sindarin will appear to reach adulthood (late teens, in human terms) after about fifty years. After about two hundred years they will appear to be about 30, at which point they stop aging.

advantage.name: Immunity to disease
advantage.description: Sindarin are immune to disease. No normal disease may affect them.

advantage.name: Hardy convalescence
advantage.description: All Sindarin have this at +6.

advantage.name: Need no sleep
advantage.description: Sindarin do not need to sleep, at least not in the human sense of the word.

advantage.name: Night vision
advantage.description: All Sindarin have this at +6.

sect3.title: Standard Sindarin Disadvantages
sect3.para: Sindarin are often seen as 'superior' to humans, but there is a reason humans have displaced the Sindarin as the dominant race on Harn, and this comes down to their immortality.
Their long lives give Sindarin are very different outlook on time. To humans, Sindarin appear lazy, distracted and indecisive. This is because Sindarin have no reason to hurry about anything.

advantage.name: Lazy
advantage.description: All Sindarin have the lazy passion at +3.

advantage.name: Distracted
advantage.description:
Sindarin are very different in outlook to humans, a fact brought on by their immortal lifespan. They have a great interest in the contemplation of nature, of philosophy and meditation. They do not take well to the sort of intensive study and training that humans seem so keep on.
If a Sindarin spends more than a week in study or training, then they suffer a -1 penalty to the quality of the source. There is a further cumulative -1 for each successive week of study. A Sindarin will be at -4 penalty for her fifth week of study.
If a break is taken from study, the penalty is reduced by one for every two weeks that pass without study. The Sindarin finds her mind drifting onto other things, and must spend time fulfilling her inner desires before continuing with such intensive study.

sect3.title: Required Advantages
sect3.para: All Sindarin are required to take (and to pay for - these are not obtained for free) each of the following.

advantage.name: Appearance
advantage.description: Sindarin must take a positive appearance.

advantage.name: Beautiful voice
advantage.description: Sindarin must take at least one level of this advantage.

advantage.name: Lithe
advantage.description: Sindarin have, on average, a higher agility than humans. This advantage gives them +1 to their agility, up to a maximum of five. Can only be taken once.

advantage.name: Perceptive
advantage.description: Sindarin have, on average, better senses than humans. This advantage gives them a +1 to their perception. Can only be taken once.

sect2.title: Khuzdul Advantages
sect2.para: The following advantages are available only to Khuzdul characters.

sect3.title: Standard Khuzdul Advantages
sect3.para: These advantages and disadvantages are held by every Khuzdul, and are gained free.

advantage.name: Possessive
advantage.description: Khuzdul tend to be very possessive. Though not exactly greedy, they are very frugal and acquisitive. They have the possessive passion at +3.

advantage.name: Loyalty (clan)
advantage.description: Khuzdul are extremely loyal to their clan, and have a loyalty of +4 toward the clan as a whole.

advantage.name: Code of Honour (dwarven)
advantage.description: A Khuzdul will never forget a friend, or foe. They will defend their freedom and possessions to the death. A dwarf can be killed, but never conquered. This does not make them stupid. They will surrender and retreat, but it is never permanent.

advantage.name: Hatred (Gargun)
advantage.description: After the actions of Lothrim the Foulspawner, dwarves have a strong hatred for all orcs. They have this passion at +3.

advantage.name: Distrust (Sindarin)
advantage.description: The Khuzdul do not trust the Sindarin, and are still upset with them over their betrayal during the battles with Lothrim. They have this at +2.

advantage.name: Brave
advantage.description: Dwarves must take this at least at +3.

advantage.name: Stubborn
advantage.description: Dwarves must take this at least at +3.

advantage.name: Enduring
advantage.description: Khuzdul tend to have a higher stamina than humans. This advantage gives +1 to stamina, up to a maximum of five.

advantage.name: Strong willed
advantage.description: Khuzdul are very strong willed, and this advantage gives +1 to will, up to a maximum of five.

sect1.title: Skills
sect1.para: Skills are those abilities which a character develops throughout their life, and tend to change a lot more regularly than attributes do.

How good a character is at a skill is rated as a value from zero upwards. A skill of four is acceptable for someone wanting to make a living with the skill. Higher skills are possible, though skills above six will be rare.
Initial character development is divided into three broad categories - general skills, professional skills and adulthood. These should be worked through in the order given below.

If the player has decided to play a non-human, then starting skills are somewhat different. This section should be read, in order to understand the ideas involved, and then the sections at the end on each of the non-human races should be used.

sect2.title: General Skills
sect2.para: A general set of skills are learned throughout the character's childhood and adolescence. For the most part, they are skills which are common to everyone.

sect3.title: Talents
sect3.para: Talents are skills which the majority of people have at least some skill at, and even people with only zero skill are capable of trying to use such skills without further penalty.
The talents are Athletics, Awareness, Brawl, Charm, Guile, Sleight, Stealth and Throw.

The player has twenty-four points to spend on these skills. No skill can be given a score above 4, and all must have a score of at least one. Skill cost is per the pyramid point cost system as used for attributes.

sect3.title: Common Knowledges
sect3.para: A character will start with a reasonable knowledge of the world they live in - though their 'world' may well be limited to a single village. This knowledge is represented by the following three starting skills, which default to the following scores.

sect3.title: Languages
sect3.para: Language skills are treated on a scale from one to four, and are not normally 'rolled' like other skills. Instead, the level of skill gives a guide to how much of a conversation a character can understand.

termlist.entry: The character can recognise the language and knows a few words, but cannot put sentences together.
The character can understand and form basic sentences. The character can probably get by in the market or in an inn.
The character has a good grasp of the language and can hold a decent conversation. They will obviously still be a foreigner however, and many unusual words will be beyond their understanding.
The character is fluent in the language. If they are a foreigner, then they may still have an accent, but they will not have any problems communicating.

If the character is a non-native speaker, then they can speak without an accent. This level and beyond gives detailed knowledge of different dialects and really obscure words, but is not of use in everyday conversation.
The language, in one dialect or another, spoken by the majority of Harnians.
Spoken by the Ivinians - the Northmen.
The language spoken in Orbaal, a mixture of Ivinian, Harnic and Jarinese. Most Ivinians speak their own language to each other.
An almost dead language, formerly used by the early Jarin settlers to Harn. Modern dialects of Jarinese are spoken by some tribes and by some stubborn Jarin.
Spoken by the Elven people of Harn.

The gargun have their own language, and each sub-race has its own variation. A skill with each sub-language is required, though other gargun languages can be spoken at the average of both skills (round down).

sect4.title: Harnic Scripts
sect4.para: The following scripts are used on Harn for written languages. A scribe skill is with a script, not with a spoken language.

termlist.entry: The script brought to Harn by human settlers from Lythia. Lakise is the principal form of writing on Harn today and remains almost identical to that still used in western Lythia.

The angular, stone-carving script, originated by the Khuzdul and still used by them. The Ivinians also use Runic. This script is common in Orbaal, and is known to many who have contact with the Khuzdul.
The aesthetic, cursive script of the Sindarin.

sect2.title: Professional Skills
sect2.para: After the character's general skills have been decided upon, the next step is to decide what the character did during apprenticeship, which takes the character up to the age of 16.
Apprenticeship provides the character with thirty points of skills to put where they want, though no skill can be raised above four at this stage.
If desired, these points can be placed on talents, as long as those skills are core to the character concept.

The pre-generated characters given later give skills generally associated with given professions, and can be used as a guide for choosing sensible skill combinations. A full list of skills, together with their descriptions is given at the end of this section, but for a brief list of commonly available skills and their difficulties, see the character sheet.

Once these skills have been assigned, the character is considered to be an adult, and ready to enter play. However, if a more experienced character is desired then it is possible to age a character beyond 16, gaining experience each further year.

sect2.title: Adulthood
sect2.para: At the age of 16, a character is assumed to be an adult, and can enter play. Many players may well feel that their character isn't quite suited to the big outdoors quite yet, and will want to develop them further.
For every year of extra development a character has before they enter play, another two points may be spent on skills.
Characters may begin at any age the player wants above 16, but characters which start above 35 years of age will have to make aging rolls before the game begins (so could possibly die).
It is suggested that characters are no more than 35 years old, for simple reasons of play balance.

sect2.title: Talents
sect2.para: The following skills are all talents, and are purchased at the initial part of character development. For most people, they will all start at a level of 2.

skill.name: Athletics
skill.description: Gymnastic and acrobatic feats are covered by this skill, including climbing, running, jumping and keeping balance.

skill.name: Awareness
skill.description: A measure of general aptitude at noticing things going on around you. Awareness checks are made to notice ambushes, hear noises, or notice unusual events. Generally used with perception.

examples.example: Hear people talking through a door
Hear people talking through a wall

skill.name: Brawl
skill.description: A general purpose combat skill covering dodging, punching and wrestling. This is covered in more detail in the combat section.

skill.name: Charm
skill.description: The ability to be nice to people, or at least make them think that you are. Calming people down, inciting them to riot, or simply trying to impress them would use this skill. Generally used with charisma, though can be used with will for organising others.
skill.example: Flirt successfully with someone (add appearance to ability roll)
Warm the heart of a guard

skill.name: Guile
skill.description:
The ability to use deceit and deception in social situations, and also to be able to counter the same. With this skill, you can lie convincingly with both words and body language, see through other people's lies and have a good idea as to their emotions.
It is used with charisma to fool others, possibly intelligence to think of a good excuse when fast talking, and perception when detecting subterfuge in others.

skill.name: Sleight
skill.description: Sleight of hand, from filching items on a market stall, to picking someone's pockets. Can also be used for anything which requires a great deal of fine dexterity.

skill.name: Stealth
skill.description: Moving quietly, hiding, and generally not being seen or heard. Based on agility for moving quietly, or perception for finding somewhere to hide.

skill.name: Throw
skill.description: Throwing things at distance with a reasonable degree of accuracy. Based on perception.

skill.name: Pvaric lore
skill.description: Knowledge of esoteric subjects, such as how magic works, the capability of magical artifacts and the like. Used mostly by members of the Shek-Pvar.

skill.name: Area lore
skill.description: Knowledge of an area, including geographical and political knowledge. Area lore is used when checking to see if a character has heard of a person, place or organisation. The area covered will be based from a given place, so a character may have several area lore skills. It is based on intelligence.

skill.name: Chirurgury
skill.description: Performing major operations on a wounded person. This requires some specialist tools (though rarely more complicated than sharp knives and tongs). It is generally only known by the Society of Physicians.

skill.name: Earthmaster Lore
skill.description: Knowledge of the legends and facts about the ancient Earthmasters. Both the sites and artifacts of the Earthmasters is covered by this knowledge.

skill.name: First aid
skill.description: Care and treatment of wounds to the extent of stopping bleeding, and preventing infection. General first aid checks are made with intelligence, though some tasks, such as removing an arrow from a wound, use dexterity.

skill.name: Faerie lore
skill.description: Knowledge of the Other World, of faeries, spirits and beasts of supernatural nature. Based on intelligence.

skill.name: Folk lore
skill.description: Knowledge of stories, myths and legends of a people. Generally, everyone has basic folk lore knowledge of their own culture.

skill.name: Genealogy
skill.description: Knowledge of the family history of a given line, normally a noble house. Based on intelligence.

skill.name: Herb lore
skill.description: Knowledge of herbs and their properties. Can be used to recognise, collect and prepare herbs and plants for use in remedies, poisons and potions. Based on intelligence.

skill.name: History
skill.description: Knowledge of the past, especially the last few hundred years. Based on intelligence.

skill.name: Law
skill.description: Knowledge and understanding of the law, and how to apply it in a given situation. Based on intelligence.

skill.name: Religion
skill.description: Knowledge of a religion, including its gods, customs and rituals. Based on intelligence.

skill.name: Speak own
skill.description: The ability to speak your own language. This defaults to four. Language skills are very rarely rolled.

skill.name: Streetwise
skill.description: Knowledge of the seedier sides of civilisation, including being able to contact influential people, deal with the thieves guild, and understand how gangs and organised crime operates within a town or city.
skill.example: Locate the best place to find contacts
Make contact with the local thieves guild safely
Get a basic understanding of the underworld in a city after a day of investigation

skill.name: Etiquette
skill.description: Knowledge of manners and how to behave in polite company. Normally based on charisma to behave correctly, or intelligence for a specific knowledge.

skill.name: Gambling
skill.description: Knowledge of how to play games of chance. Guile is often also useful for bluffing and guessing what other people are up to. A guile roll can give a one-fifth bonus to the gambling skill roll. Normally based on intelligence.

skill.name: Lip reading
skill.description: The skill of reading lips. Each 10 rolled gives an equivalent point of language skill. There may be penalties for distance, or partial visibility.

skill.name: Orating
skill.description: The ability to give speeches to inspire passions in people. This skill is based on charisma.

skill.name: Play (instrument)
skill.description: The skill needed to play a musical instrument. There is a separate skill for each type of instrument. Possible types of instrument include string, percussion and wind.

skill.name: Poetry
skill.description: The knowledge of poems, and the ability to improvise new poems. Reciting a poem is charisma based, inventing a new poem is intelligence based.

skill.name: Sing
skill.description: The ability to sing well and in a way to entertain people. Includes knowledge of songs, and the ability to choose and improvise songs to fit an occasion. It is charisma based to sing well, intelligence based to choose or improvise a song.

skill.name: Teach
skill.description: The ability to teach another person, and train them in the use of a skill. See the Campaign section for details on training.

skill.name: Trade
skill.description: Covers a multitude of skills involved with trading, including bartering, and having some clue as to the value of goods.

sect2.title: Cult Skills
sect2.para: Cult skills are only available to members of a given religion. In theory, they can be learned by anyone, but it is generally forbidden to teach them outside of the cult.

skill.name: Berserker
skill.description: This skill is only known by the clerics and fighting orders of Agrik. It mimics the advantage of the same name. It is based on stamina, and each 10 points rolled gives an equivalence to one level of berserker advantage.

skill.name: Dream lore
skill.description: It is believed that dreams give glimpses of the inner mind of a person, and also of their future. The ability to understand dreams, and to garner useful knowledge from them is difficult to master. At worst though, someone with this skill can give impressive interpretations of a dream, if not entirely accurate. Based on intelligence, and taught by the priests of Siem.

skill.name: Erotic arts
skill.description: The skill of giving (and taking) pleasure to someone. It is unique to the priestesses of Halea, and a few favoured followers (mainly members of the guild of courtesans). Normally base on dexterity.

skill.name: Riddle lore
skill.description: This is the skill of solving riddles and puzzles, of understanding the links connecting broken facts. It is taught by the priests of Save-K'nor.

skill.name: Torture
skill.description: A skill honed to perfection by the followers of Agrik. This gives knowledge of the 'ten thousand ways of pain'. It includes knowledge of anatomy, psychology and implements of torture. Normally based on intelligence.

skill.name: Boating
skill.description: Being able to use a small oared boat. Based on intelligence for judging travel conditions, strength for speed or dexterity for fine navigation.

skill.name: Falconry
skill.description: The skill of training, caring for and hunting with falcons and similar birds of prey.

skill.name: Hunting
skill.description: The skill of training, caring for and hunting with hounds.

skill.name: Ride
skill.description: The ability to ride, normally a horse. A different skill is needed for different types of animals (horses and ponies would be the same skill, a Griffin another skill). As well as enabling you to remain mounted, it grants a bonus to combat skills when mounted.

skill.name: Survival
skill.description: Knowledge of how to get by in the wilderness, from finding food, trapping animals, and moving at speed across country.

skill.name: Swim
skill.description: The ability to move in water without drowning or panicking. Basically, a waterborne version of the athletics skill.

skill.name: Track
skill.description: The ability to find, identify and follow tracks left by animals and people. To follow a single person across soft terrain is moderate difficulty. Muddy terrain, or a large number of people or creatures makes it easier. An opposed tracking roll can be used to hide tracks.

sect2.title: Professional Skills
sect2.para: Professional skills will not often be learned by player characters, however they will be the most common skills known by people in the world.

Each professional skill covers those tasks performed by someone who makes their living. As well as the actual obvious use of the skill, the skill can be used to evaluate the quality of raw materials and finished goods, estimate prices and set up and run a business based around the profession.
Some skills are only taught as part of a guilded occupation. Learning them if the character is not apprenticed to a master will be difficult.

skill.name: Armoury
skill.description: Making armour such as chain mail or ring mail, but also includes leather armour as well.

skill.name: Beekeeping
skill.description: The keeping of bees, and the harvesting of honey from them.

skill.name: Blacksmithing
skill.description: Metal working, including needles, horseshoes, tools and so on. It can be used to make knives and daggers, but anything larger requires the weaponsmithing skill.

skill.name: Bowyer
skill.description: The making of bows and arrows.

skill.name: Brewing
skill.description: Brewing beer and ale. This skill is generally the domain of the ale wives in small villages.

skill.name: Candlemaking
skill.description: The making of candles.

skill.name: Carpentry
skill.description: Crafting items out of wood, from chairs to houses.

skill.name: Clothier
skill.description: Working with cloth, generally in the making of clothes. Can be used for making leather or padded armour if necessary, though this is not normally the domain of clothiers.

skill.name: Cooking
skill.description: The preparing, preserving and cooking of food. Includes some knowledge of herbs.

skill.name: Copicing
skill.description: The care and management of woodland. All manors will have someone skilled in this, and it is not uncommon for such a person to be a carpenter as well.

skill.name: Dairying
skill.description: The making of cheese and other dairy products. Includes caring for and milking cows.

skill.name: Farming
skill.description: The planting, caring for and harvesting of crops, the care and feeding of animals such as cows, sheep and chickens. The majority of people in rural areas will of course be farmers.

skill.name: Glassworking
skill.description: The making of glassware, though this is a rare, and highly sought after, skill.

skill.name: Handicraft
skill.description: The making of baskets, embroidery and other similar village hand crafts not covered by other professional skills.

skill.name: Jewelcraft
skill.description: The crafting of jewelry and gems. Covers artistic skill, as well as knowledge of the values of such items.

skill.name: Masonry
skill.description: The building of houses, bridges and other constructions out of stone.

skill.name: Milling
skill.description: Running a mill, from the grinding of flour to the baking of the bread.

skill.name: Mining
skill.description: Covers being able to locate new mines, and to construct and work them safely.

skill.name: Ostling
skill.description: The care and training of horses.

skill.name: Potter
skill.description: Pottery.

skill.name: Shipwright
skill.description: Ship building.

skill.name: Tanning
skill.description: Tanning.

skill.name: Thatching
skill.description: Thatching.

skill.name: Weaponsmithing
skill.description: The making of weapons, including spears, daggers, swords and axes. The making of bows and arrows is a different profession, which is covered by bowyer.

skill.name: Weaving
skill.description: A profession which includes weaving and spindling.

sect2.title: Combat Skills
sect2.para: See the combat chapter for a complete description of how these skills are used. Generally, a skill in a particular weapon is not necessary, just a style of fighting.

skill.name: Battle
skill.description: Knowledge of tactics and strategy for planning, and fighting, large scale battles (anything with a dozen or more people a side). Combined with charisma, it is also used for leadership in battle.

skill.name: Bow
skill.description: Using either a shortbow or longbow.

skill.name: Crossbow
skill.description: Using any type of crossbow.

skill.name: Great weapon
skill.description: Using a large weapon such as a great sword.

skill.name: Longshaft weapon
skill.description: Fighting with a spear, quarterstaff, pike, lance or similar long shafted weapon. If the weapon is being used one handed, then a shield may be used as well. The lance can be used one handed with a shield from horseback.

skill.name: Single Weapon
skill.description: Fighting with a single melee weapon and no shield.

skill.name: Two handed weapon
skill.description: Fighting with a two handed weapon such as a great sword.

skill.name: Two weapons
skill.description: Fighting with a weapon in each hand, such as with two swords for example.

skill.name: Weapon and shield
skill.description: Fighting with a weapon and shield.
